description: The verb is from Middle English distressen, from Old French destrecier (“to restrain, constrain, put in straits, afflict, distress”); compare French détresse. Ultimately from Medieval Latin as if *districtiare, an assumed frequentative form of Latin distringere (“to pull asunder, stretch out”), from dis- (“apart”) + stringere (“to draw tight, strain”).
The noun is from Middle English distresse, from Old French destrece, ultimately also from Latin distringere.

entries.meaning: Physical or emotional discomfort, suffering, or alarm, particularly of a more acute nature.
(medicine) An aversive state of stress to which a person cannot fully adapt.
(law) A seizing of property without legal process to force payment of a debt.
(law) The thing taken by distraining; that which is seized to procure satisfaction.
examples: If he were not paid, he would straight go and take a distress of goods and cattle.

verbs.description: distress (third-person singular simple present distresses, present participle distressing, simple past and past participle distressed)

entries.meaning: To cause strain or anxiety to someone.
examples: Synonyms: anguish, harrow, trouble, vex, torment, tantalize, tantalise, martyr

entries.meaning: (law) To retain someone’s property against the payment of a debt; to distrain.
To treat a new object to give it an appearance of age.
examples: She distressed the new media cabinet so that it fit with the other furniture in the room.
